title: Secure Architectures of Future Emerging Cryptography

author: Gavin McWilliams, The Institute of Electronics, Communications and Information Technology (ECIT), Queen's University Belfast

segmentation: Alright, OK, we're there so thank you very much, Tom and Nsai for hosting us and asking me to to present as Mary said I work in Belfast, Queens University Belfast is by 150 kilometres North of here.
I work in a cyber security Research Institute called CSAT.
Center for Secure Information Technologies sees it is recognized by the UK Research Council as an academic center of excellence in cyber security research work.
Encompases applied cryptography, which is the main theme of this talk, but we also do considerable amounts of work around critical infrastructure protection, smart grids and.
Industrial control systems.

We do a lot of work on malware detection on IP traffic analysis, anomaly detection and specialized intrusion detection systems, and we also do some work on biometrics on security, data analytics and decision support systems.
Ultimately, decision support systems.
And the mix, I guess of what we've got going in Belfast this it's a fairly big unit as is.
Close on 100 people there at the moment means that we we do hardware development.
We do software development, but our sweet spot I guess is around embedded systems and systems of systems.
So we're well placed in to look at the cyber security challenges of the Internet of Things, and that's largely our main theme of our research agenda going forward.
But going forward with this presentation, the future of cryptography or emerging cryptography.
Ascentia Lee comes down to this box and Unbox is similar to it.

This is a large and very expensive computer produced by a a fairly small Canadian company called D Wave who market this or started marketing this in 2012 is the world's first commercial quantum computer.
Now the jury is, to some extent still out as to whether this is a true quantum computer.
But this has been going for a few years.
This is rated as a 512 qubit machine, cubit being the information element used inside quantum computers.
A bit like a bet in classical computing, but it's a little bit more subtle than that within the quantum space.
It is difficult to see whether the D wave machine is producing.
The full results that we would expect from a universal quantum computer.
And their technical people, not their marketing.
People, have now admitted that the technique that they're using is known as quantum annealing, which is kind of like.
A simulation of quantum mechanical operations taking place in the CPU.
They're not really running them natively, but they're they're doing it via an emulation.
And, well, who cares if they can do the emulation fast enough then so be it?
Well, you would think so, but in actual fact that's not the case.

And really, this machine so shows some speedups of some operations, particularly problems around optimization and sampling, but it doesn't perform any faster than desktop PC in a lot of other application spaces.
And that's a very, very expensive desktop PC, so the technical jury is still out.
I guess on this machine, and it has a Big Brother released this year, which is 1000 cubits.
But from a commercial perspective, I still find this very interesting.
These machines have been sold through to Lockheed Martin large security prime in the US, and also Google and NASA.
And the Google slash NASA is because they are sharing the machine which I find interesting because Google with a market capitalization of 504 billion US dollars.
Didn't have enough money to buy one of these machines or couldn't construct a business case to buy one of these machines, which I find fascinating.
However, Lockheed Martin, who have a market capitalization of 67 US billion dollars, can buy one of these and is using it.
And that's an interesting fact.
And maybe this is one of the reasons for that.
So the US National Security Agency.
Would be Edward Snowden's X employer?

It it became apparent to early last year that the NSA were spending almost $80,000,000 to perform a feasibility study, not to build a quantum computer, but to carry out a feasibility study into the physics and some studies around architecture and engineering required to see whether they could produce a cryptologic.
Lee useful quantum computer.
And what would you do with a crypto logically useful quantum computer?
You would break strong encryption.
And where would you break that encryption?
Well, it would need to break hard targets.
It needs to penetrate hard targets.
So we're left asking.
Well, I wonder what a hard target is.
So if if we take it for granted that at some stage within the next 10 or 15 years we do see a true universal quantum computer, what will be the fallout?
And today's security.
A lot of the encryption security certainly used within the Internet is based on this set of algorithms.
Crypto algorithms such as RSA and elliptic curve Diffie Hellman key Exchange.
There are all the keys.
Or key technologies that are used in many of the Internet security systems in place today.
And the thing that is common across all of those algorithms is that mathematically, they're all based on 2 problems.
Either difficulties in Factorizing large prime numbers or the discrete log problem, and our problem is that a researcher and IBM Peter Shor came up with an algorithm.
A quantum algorithm several years ago, which cuts through those problems like a knife through butter.
If shores outer them runs on a real quantum computer, then all of that security, all of that encryption.
All of those digital certificates that are sitting on your PC at the moment are completely useless.
And that's the issue that we're facing.
This all relates to public key infrastructures.
The simpler symmetric key algorithms will still stay secure against quantum computers, and in particular Grover's algorithm.
Simply by increasing the size of the keys, they should.
They should last but symmetric.
Key cryptography is is more limited, doesn't scale well.
So large scale Internet applications push more towards PKI.
So that's really the reasoning for us to start looking at.
Quantum CF cryptography, also known as post quantum cryptography, and this is forms of conventional cryptography that will remain secure even in the fierce of attack from quantum computers.
There are four main areas or themes of research going on at the moment and to post quantum cryptography code based hash based multivariate, quadratic and lattices.
Lattice based cryptography is the area that we are particularly interested in in Belfast, and the advantages of lattice based crypto is that the.
The basic primitives can be implemented very efficiently in hardware and software.

We've already seen that happening, and it also provides a very firm platform of base that we can build on so that we can move beyond simple encryption and signature type primitives into more exotic forms of protection such as identity based encryption, attribute based encryption and ultimately homomorphic encryption.
I can't go into an awful lot of detail in these are.
Maybe you're delighted to hear that I won't go into a great deal.

And these, but we are currently involved in a Horizon 2020 project which started in January of this year called See If Crypto and the goal of that project then is to bring forward a set of practical and robust physically secure lattice based crypto solutions that will ensure.
Long term security of our ICT systems and services and long-term in this sense means 40 years.
50 years hence.
And see if Crypto project then you know looks are will attempt to apply these solutions in three key studies.

One looking at satellites and satellite communications, another looking at emergency first responder communication systems and the third one is in the area of big data and data analytics and preserving privacy in those environments.
So the first one is about space.
Satellites currently have their cryptographic keys loaded up onto them, and then the countdown starts and it shot off into space.
The satellites stay up there of course, for 40 odd years in service, there's no way of changing or updating or improving the cryptosystems that are there.
It's fixed from launch.

And that's maybe OK if we're talking about small numbers of satellites and individual owners, but what's about to happen is we're going to see constellations of low orbit satellites, maybe 7000 satellites in in one cluster.
If you like that, are moving continuously above us, and as they provide services, then they've got a handoff.
Service from one satellite to the next one as they move above us, we're stationary and they're moving.
So.

You then need a network and you then need the satellites to talk to each other, as well as talking to the ground stations, and for a lot of those reasons the industry is pushing towards public key solutions.
So we see this as a good opportunity for us to try and embed some of our lattice based crypto work and see if we can we can show its benefit in that environment.
The second use case is on public safety communications.
The kind of.

Public safety comms solutions that are used across Europe at the moment are predominantly spin out of the GSM standardization mobile network standardization activities taking place in the mid 80s, early 90s.
And Tetra is is the dominant system in Europe at the moment.
Within against 2025, 2020.
Yet we will see a technology uplift coming through for that network.
So Tetra I guess is sitting in what we could term 2G network or two and a half G network.
But this time we get around to 2025.
The this this area public safety columns are going to be using either LTE networks or 5G networks.
And the difference is that.
Tetra at the moment is based on Circuit switched voice.
Voice circuit carries your conversation from A to B and nobody else has access to that circuit.
It's fairly secure, but when we move to LTE and five G and those networks, there's no circuit switching.
They are packet data networks.
These are data services, so that's not a hot.
That's not a phone as such that you're holding up to your mouth.

It's a computer sitting on an IP network and that computer on an IP network is just as vulnerable as any PC sitting on the Internet, so the security around that and how we make and keep that secure in that environment is another good opportunity for us to show the benefits of our work.
And in this instance we will be looking at identity based encryption.
Methods.
The third one then, is around Big Data.
I guess the scenario is that Dublin City Council collects much data about its citizens and holds onto that in a secure fashion.
But if they wanted to provide Open Access to that data to third party service providers to academics to other department's, and then go to access control problem.

And we believe that we can help to solve that using an approach called attribute based encryption, where essentially it means that the keys, the cryptographic keys that you give to the third party's over to the academics or the other department's those keys will determine what view that person that user has off the data store.

As in, one user can see one set of columns of the database, but another user doesn't, or one user sees a geographic representation or view of the data or restricted view in geographic terms, and so on.
So that's our third area that we're looking at.
Anne.
Just to underline the kind of timeliness I guess of this work, the US National Institute for Standards NIST specifies.
The set of cryptographic algorithms that have been approved for use within secure systems or federal systems in US government, but it's also widely used by industry players as well.
And that suite of algorithms is imaginatively called Suite B. Suite B cryptographic algorithms.
NSA of justice produced as in August of this year.
I've just produced guidance saying that the sweet Suite B algorithms are going to be replaced and transitioned to quantum.
See if quantum resistant algorithms in in the future.
We don't know when that's going to happen, to the best of our knowledge, they don't have a suite of quantum.
See if.

Algorithms to to replace sweet be with, but they're warning everyone, and I guess this is the first time the US administration has warned anyone that there is an issue with quantum cryptography and the issues that are coming down the line soon.
So.
So to summarize, the Safe Crypto project started in January of this year.
We have another three years to run, is coordinated by ourselves in Queens, Belfast and a lot of our theoretical work is coming out of Paris, INRIA sortable.

And a lot of the physical security and resistance side channel attacks is coming from the University of Lugano in Switzerland and our hardware implementations are being driven by Boca Music University in Germany.
EMC and in Cork and their security division based out of Switzerland, RSA are looking at the municipal data.
Used Kia's history communications and SMEs and Lancaster and North England are specialists in the Tetra and the public.
Safety communications work, so they're heading that up and then tell as UK their their technology and labs in reading are providing us with the support on the satellite.
Use kious directly for one of the towers operating divisions, Alina Tellers, Alena who build and deploy satellites and that that is.
Our consortium.
You can find more information on the safe crypto dot EU website and other than that I thank you very much for your time.
